text: As of today, San Mateo is the only Bay Area county not on the stateâ€™s coronavirus watch list. But that could change soon, and beauty salons, houses of worship, and other indoor businesses are trying to hang onto a small sense of normalcy. https://t.co/LkLfjoCzBB

name: sfchronicle
text: There were 997 infected prisoners at San Quentin as of Saturday, a drop from 1,118 on Friday, prison officials reported. The prison has seen 452 new cases over the past 14 days, and has reported recorded 12 deaths so far from COVID-19. https://t.co/MRNec6ZXMR

name: sfchronicle
text: A large new study from South Korea finds that children younger than 10 transmit to others much less often than adults do, but the risk is not zero. And those between the ages of 10 and 19 can spread the virus at least as well as adults do. https://t.co/ZIYZc7Qlqp

name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco City Hall will be illuminated in red, white and blue tonight in honor of Rep. John Lewis, the civil rights icon who died on Friday at age 80. The city will also lower its flags to half-staff to honor the congressman. https://t.co/xvaFib3Z5E

name: sfchronicle
text:

text:
The coronavirus pandemic is widening the divide among Bay Area religious institutions. Small mosques, synagogues and churches are struggling while larger, wealthier houses of worship are bringing in more money from donors than ever before.
